labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Document structure
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
Intro: What is obliviousness?
- Should the main term be obliviousness? Separation of contexts (identity from what is being accessed)
- Is obliviousness just half of the problem? What's the name for the overall concept? Partitioning?

Why is it important? What problem is it solving?
- User privacy
- Reduce liability of entities holding too much data, reduce consolidation of data
- Make sure data is only shared with parties that make sense for a given item

Common trend emerging:
- ODoH
- OHTTP
- MASQUE (see also generic proxying and VPN)
- PrivacyPass
- PPM/PRIO

Definition and terminology
- Different parties involved
- Different types of contexts
- Types of communication
- Trust relationships

Partitioned architectures
- Different models of how to arrange the parties
- Framework for how to analyze privacy properties of an partitioned model
- Ways to analyze trust, how privacy breaks down if assumptions are violated (collapses to non-partitioned model)

Impacts on existing deployments
- Network management and visibility; can network elements become involved to fix this
- Server visibility of data changes

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Maybe name: "Dissociation"?

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: PPM is calling its document "Distributed Aggregation" — so "distributed" is another useful word here.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: "Partitioning", "Privacy Partitions", "Privacy Partitioning"?

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: "Private Data Partitioning"?

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
For grouping the specific protocols:

- Partitioning along a network path: OHTTP/ODoH, MASQUE
- Transitive identifiers across partitions: Privacy Pass
- Data transformation across partitions: PPM

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I added some more text but I think we want to discuss a bit more about these general models before we submit -00

issues.title: Rename to "Decoupling"?
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: Another term instead of partitioning is Decoupling. The Principle of Decoupling, The Decoupling Principle, etc.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I like privacy partitioning more...

comments.author: fluffy
comments.body: I prefer the partitioning over decoupling

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: if you look for privacy and data partitioning, you sooner or later will end up discussing k-anonymity where I believe this is the appropriate reference: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1142/S0218488502001648

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Also note that there is also privacy preserving data mining (PPDM) as a term of art (what is exactly what is used in PPM). Some example survey papers that might provide some overview (didn't read them yet fully):
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4643068/
https://www.ijert.org/research/techniques-for-privacy-preservation-in-data-mining-IJERTV4IS100473.pdf

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Closing based on discussion.

issues.title: Layers of decoupling
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
MASQUE / OHTTP decouple data on a network path. Decoupling in space, effectively.

Other decoupling strategies necessarily have to build on top of that.

PPM decouples based on computation, but relies on separate servers / network paths.

Privacy Pass decouples trust/attestation using blinding, and also relies on decoupled paths.

issues.title: Partitioning/decoupling relies on only one party knowing the joined set
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
In these models, only the client knows the fully joined set of information. No server individually knows how to join all the data.

TLS and ECH are good examples of using encryption to hide information from most parties, but in that case clients and servers (two entities) still can join all informations. VPNs were like that too.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @tfpauly I think we can close this now.

issues.title: Everything is more explicit
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
Clients want to be able to be explicit about what data they share — location, etc.

In order to do this, they need to explicitly select different entities and hops over which to partition data.

As a result, these entities need to actively/more explicitly collude in order to rejoin data.

issues.title: Partitioning/decoupling doesn't prevent side-channel attacks
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
Timing side-channels, etc, are still possible. They can of course be mitigated in very expensive ways to fuzz the data, but it's important to point out that this general architecture doesn't prevent these attacks.

It does, however, move the threat model to this kind of analysis rather than just looking at direct metadata.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
We do have text on this:
"For example, side channels such as traffic analysis [[I-D.irtf-pearg-website-fingerprinting](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#I-D.irtf-pearg-website-fingerprinting)] or timing analysis are still possible and can allow an unauthorized entity to learn information about a context they are not a participant of."

issues.title: Notation for analyzing partitioning
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
The decoupling paper charts out:
- Sensitive identity
- Non-sensitive identity
- Sensitive data/metadata
- Non-sensitive data/metadata

However, it may be simpler to just track the sensitive things.

Like in ODoH, the relay sees sensitive identity but not data, and target sees sensitive data but not identity.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
Different parties involved
Different types of contexts
Types of communication
Trust relationships

issues.title: Add pictures / diagrams
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: Generic one as well as per-protocol

issues.title: Describe analysis of models
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
- Different models of how to arrange the parties
- Framework for how to analyze privacy properties of an partitioned model
- Ways to analyze trust, how privacy breaks down if assumptions are violated (collapses to non-partitioned model)

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: This is where we should define the notation for #9 ?

issues.title: Add references to RFC 6973
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: We should explain the relationship to RFC 6973, the previous IAB document on privacy.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Yes, need to say something here. This is the respective text from RFC6973:
see https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-6.1.4

```
6.1.4  Data Minimization within Identity Management

   Modern systems are increasingly relying on multi-party transactions
   to authenticate individuals.  Many of these systems make use of an
   identity provider that is responsible for providing AAA functionality
   to relying parties that offer some protected resources.  To
   facilitate these functions, an identity provider will usually go
   through a process of verifying the individual's identity and issuing
   credentials to the individual.  When an individual seeks to make use
   of a service provided by the relying party, the relying party relies
   on the authentication assertions provided by its identity provider.
   Note that in more sophisticated scenarios the authentication
   assertions are traits that demonstrate the individual's capabilities
   and roles.  The authorization responsibility may also be shared
   between the identity provider and the relying party and does not
   necessarily need to reside only with the identity provider.

   Such systems have the ability to support a number of properties that
   minimize data collection in different ways:

      In certain use cases, relying parties do not need to know the real
      name or date of birth of an individual (for example, when the
      individual's age is the only attribute that needs to be
      authenticated).

      Relying parties that collude can be prevented from using an
      individual's credentials to track the individual.  That is, two
      different relying parties can be prevented from determining that
      the same individual has authenticated to both of them.  This
      typically requires identity management protocol support as well as
      support by both the relying party and the identity provider.

      The identity provider can be prevented from knowing which relying
      parties an individual interacted with.  This requires, at a
      minimum, avoiding direct communication between the identity
      provider and the relying party at the time when access to a
      resource by the initiator is made.
```

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Partly done with #14

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @mirjak do you want to take this one?

issues.title: Discuss attestation bit more?
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
The impacts section should talk about attestation, etc.

> ## Attestation (and identity management)
> 
> Simple techniques like encryption or a more flexible use of IP addresses, e.g. based on proxying, gives the user more control about its data and is a prerequisite for practical partitioning. This is especially important for metadata which have unintentionally been spread to more entities than functionally needed in the past. 
> 
> Looking further at the data that is requested by a service to function, and not only unintentionally revealed metadata, different services of course have different requirements. Some services do require a user identity, e.g. by creating a user account. Other services currently use existing identifiers like the IP address to create a notion of identity, e.g. to rate-limit access to a certain service or track their service usage. Particularly, in these cases there is a desire to minimize the number of entities that can identify the user. However, just concealing any identifying data by partitioning can impact the service function.
> 
> In these cases privacy partitioning can be “used” together with attestation where a known trusted entity that can access a user’s identity can attest a certain characteristic or property of the user without revealing the identity.
> 
> ToDo: Given an example?
>

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Not sure this belongs in the impact section.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I think the W3C verifiable credentials work (see https://www.w3.org/2017/vc/WG/), that @fluffy mentioned in the IAB call today, might fit here as well.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Actually I don't think we need this anymore. I mainly thought it would be useful to also define attestation in the context of this draft but I guess that is covered by the privacy pass section.

The interesting difference for privacy pass compared to the other approach is maybe that you have a "new" entity that is not on-path. A) this enables you to also do time partitioning, and b) this is something that can be combined with the other approaches. So I have the feeling the is something more we need to discuss here...

issues.title: Performance and privacy tussle
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: Do we want to say something about connection coalescing as an example of the (often present) performance and privacy? See [this comment](https://github.com/intarchboard/draft-obliviousness/pull/21#discussion_r987974304) for more context.

issues.title: Use SVG
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: Currently, the SVG diagrams have bad text alignment. We need to fix that before we use it.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Fixed by #27

issues.title: Acknowledge and cite Decoupling Principle paper
issues.author: tfpauly

issues.title: Multiple disjoint contexts need to be truly disjoint
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
[Section 2.1](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#section-2.1-9) says:

> Another way to create a partition is to simply use separate connections. For example, to split two separate HTTP requests from one another, a client could issue the requests on separate TCP connections, each on a different network, and at different times; and avoid including obvious identifiers like HTTP cookies across the requests.

This could probably be improved by pointing out that all identifiers that might be shared across contexts might be used to correlate activity.  This acts at all layers of the stack, with some layers providing less linkability as a result of them maybe being shared with others (IP address, MAC address maybe, device fingerprints, based on hardware and software choices) that might be unique when considered in totality, whereas others provide absolute linkability (per-client cookies).

I don't know how much existing work can be pointed to on this point, but it's a central piece of the overall thesis you are tackling here.

issues.title: Is MASQUE different than CONNECT?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
[Section 3.1](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#section-3.1-2) says:

> There is also a Proxy-to-Target context; in case of MASQUE this context only contains any (unprotected) packet header information that is added or modified by the proxy, e.g., the IP and UDP headers.

This implies that the HTTP CONNECT case is materially different.  I don't think that is true.

Secondarily, you should say "UDP/TCP" here.

issues.title: CONNECT and encryption
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
[Section 3.1](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#section-3.1-1) says:

> HTTP forward proxies, when using encryption, provide privacy partitioning by separating a connection into multiple segments. 

I think that you need to be explicit here about what is encrypted.  Traditionally, there is no encryption on the client-proxy connection.  However, some browsers support HTTPS proxies, which adds encryption to that link.

I don't know which of these modes this section refers to.  This will be relevant in my next issue.

issues.title: End-to-end context for CONNECT/MASQUE
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
Isn't there an end-to-end context for CONNECT/MASQUE?  If the tunneled connection is encrypted, then the content of that connection is not visible to the proxy.

All the diagrams in [Section 3.1](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#section-3.1) show the proxy in this context, but [Figure 2](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#figure-2) doesn't.

(I infer that you aren't concerned about any leakage out of a context at this level.  Leakage is a concern, but it's probably OK to leave that to a later section of the document.)

issues.title: Secondary contexts
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: [Figure 4](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#figure-4) and [Figure 5](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#figure-5) shows a bunch of contexts in which the client does not participate.  Are those really helpful to include?

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: I think these are useful to include, personally, since they show the contexts across the entire flow. While client privacy is the goal, partitioning works in general. Happy to hear other opinions, though!

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Yeah, I think we ought to include them. Maybe we should add text that actually references them though? For example, we might say that, in the two hop arrangement, Proxy B sees: context is shares with the Client (TLS session), context it shares with Proxy A (IP address and transport bits), and context it shares with the Target (transport and TLS session).

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: We do talk about them a bit, and my new text from #32 may help make it clearer by having a separate bullet?

issues.title: Fingerprinting
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: A more thorough treatment of this subject might be helpful in [Section 4](https://intarchboard.github.io/draft-obliviousness/draft-kpw-iab-privacy-partitioning.html#section-4).  Fingerprinting exploits characteristics of a client that are innate and therefore difficult to remove.  This includes details of implementation of protocols in hardware and software, and network location.  This manifests in patterns that can, when combined, produce a value that can be used to re-identify clients across contexts.

issues.title: Trust is important
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From the list: 

> The document should state very clearly that the net effect of 
these architectures on user privacy will be positive or negative 
depending on who is in control of the choice of where the traffic goes. 

This seems reasonable to do!

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Related this discussion we could maybe also add a note on centralisation risks (if there is no user choice in the deployment) in the impacts section but need to figure out more clearly what is useful to say in this document (or what should be left to other docs on centralization).

issues.title: Section: Violations by Collusion
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
Jari by email:

> Perhaps you should describe the possibility that outside parties -- such
> as authorities -- force collusion by law or authoritative requests.
> This seems like a quite likely danger.
> 
> (Given how central the assumptions around collusion are on this,
> I’d like to see a deeper discussion on this.)

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Not sure. Seems like a separate topic on its own for me. But maybe we can mention it somewhere?

Maybe just say something like: "Even if entities don't collude directly, if information is revealed to another party, which e.g. could be required by legal obligations, there is no control about further collusion of data."

issues.title: Expand security considerations
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
Comment by Jari:

> Besides collusion, timing attacks and traffic analysis continue to be concerns. 
> I think these methods have issues that are more specific than general issues
> In this space, and would perhaps be useful to describe in more detail.
> 
> It is also seems to be not just a purely matter of server1 and server2 colluding.
> Even observation of traffic on some leg(s) and inside knowledge from server2
> seems sufficient for determining correlation. FWIW, I don’t claim to fully
> understand what the issues are (despite working on similar things for something
> slightly different in the past), but my point is that the draft is really brief on this,
> and I think there’s more to unpack.

issues.title: Do we need/want a privacy considerations section per RFC6973?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: (Question raised by Niels via mail)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Given that the whole document is about privacy considerations, I think we can probably close this without action. @mirjak, @tfpauly, what do you think?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Generally I agree but I guess we could say exactly this in one sentence.

issues.title: talk about why a diversity of approaches have been developed
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
By MT via mail:

> There are clearly parts of the draft that are more refined than others and I'm not sure that it always stays neatly within its implied scope.  I'm also interested in whether that scope might be expanded to talk about why a diversity of approaches have been developed.  That might provide some basis for understanding the properties of each approach so that people might understand where each applies best.

issues.title: Add text on linkable identifiers
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: Linkability may happen by looking at information across different layers of the stack, e.g., as discussed in [this old draft](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-wood-linkable-identifiers/).

issues.title: Generalize beyond encryption
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: Encryption isn't the only cryptographic tool at our disposal for separating contexts, though it is the most obvious and easy-to-use one.

comments.body:

```suggestion
read by passively observing traffic and therefore giving the control of its data back to the user.
```

```suggestion
However, this is not sufficient to ensure good or the best possible user privacy.
```

```suggestion
important to separate user identity (who) from user actions (what) whenever possible.
```

```suggestion
read by passively observing traffic and thereby giving the control of its data back to the user.
```

```suggestion
multiple parties as a means to improve the privacy by separating user identity from user actions.
```

Could we make this extra thought a separate sentence? It seems to run on.

```suggestion
read by passively observing traffic.
```

```suggestion
However, this is not sufficient to provide a complete user privacy solution.
```

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: This was just and idea that this topic is highly related (after reading Jana's/chris' paper). However, it might be out of scope, therefore I left it in a separate PR for now. Please review!

Probably better as a separate section from the intro.

Identity brokers (like sign-in with apple, etc) do things to hide direct identity from end services, but the brokers can see the real and anonymized identity still. We could try to apply the split here. It's a similar and related area, and maybe could benefit from this analysis.

```suggestion
These works mainly focus one communication protocol support for privacy partitioning.
A remaining challenging also lives in identity management itself. Today, mainly services
implement their own identify management (requiring separate account of each service) or
```

```suggestion
access rights or other relevant user characteristics in an anonymous way. However, today use of
the centralized system rather lead to an even larger centralization of data as user activity is
not sufficiently revealed from the identity management system, and identity is not anonymized by
the management system.
```
that on-going work is looking at protocols but not identify management...

pulls.title: Analysis and applications of partitioning
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body:
I think more can probably be said here. In no particular order:

1. How one recognizes possible applications of the principle.
2. How one applies the principle to new systems or protocols. 

I couldn't come up with a concise yet useful way to articulate these, so I'd be happy to hear suggestions!

comments.body: Saying it's straightforward makes it sound a bit trivial... which maybe is good to make it sound easy, but it also does have large impacts =)

```suggestion
The most impactful types of user-identifying information to partition are (a) user identity or identities that can be linked and (b) user data.
```
Maybe we say it's a conceptually simple process? As in, "easier said than done"?

```suggestion
It is not currently possible to guarantee with technical protocol measure that two
entities are not colluding. However, there are some mitigations that can be applied
to reduce the risk of collusion happening in practice:
```

```suggestion
Applying privacy partitioning to an existing or new system or protocol requires the following steps:
```

```suggestion
1. Identify the types of information used or exposed in a system or protocol, some of which can be used to identity a user or correlate to other contexts.
```
I'm concerned that just partitioning out the data that is obviously user-identifying isn't enough; how can we capture the correlation angle too?

```suggestion
1. Partition different types of user-identifying or correlatable information across contexts to minimize the amount of
user-identifying or correlatable information in any single context.

```

```suggestion
This partitioning process can be applied incorrectly or incompletely. Partitions may contain
```

```suggestion
than intended. Nevertheless, partitions can help improve the client's privacy posture when applied carefully.
```
I think your suggested text probably covers it, which states that two contexts must not be trivially correlated through any shared or common info.

```suggestion
1. Identify the types of information used or exposed in a system or protocol, some of which can be used to identify a user or correlate to other contexts.
```

> (a) user identity or identities that can be linked and (b) user data.

I think I still don't understand the difference here. Isn't the case of Oblivious HTTP actually that you separate user-identifying information (IP address) from other usually non-user-identifying information (http request)?

> minimize the amount of  user-identifying or correlatable information in any single context.

Per discussion slack, I actually think this is not fully correct and also not what we say earlier. Earlier we talk about separate the who from the what and minimising amount of information needed to fulfill a function to only reveal user-specific information to parties that need access to the information for their intended purpose.

```suggestion
1.  Separate user-identifying information from other user data in different contexts and reduce the amount of
user-identifying or correlatable information in each context to the minimum needed to fulfil the intended function.
```

I'm not sure I follow you, since that's exactly what the text here says. That is, it says the most important things to separate are information relating to user identity (IP address) and user data (HTTP request).

```suggestion
than intended. Moreover, splitting user-identifying information over multiple contexts has to be done with care, as creating more contexts can increase the number of entities that need to be trusted to not collude.
Nevertheless, partitions can help improve the client's privacy posture when applied carefully.
```
Here we use the term "partition". I guess that actually the same as context, no? I think it like partition actually more as it's the natural term and probably needs actually less explanation.

```suggestion
on the entities that participate in each context that exist and types of user-identifying information as well as other data in each context. Such evaluation is
```

```suggestion
The most impactful partitioning is separating user-identifying information from other user data.
```
it's not quite what the text says because it currently says that user data (b) is also user-identifying information which is confusing.

User data _can_ be user-identifying, since it's data about or generated by the user. This is an important point I don't think we can omit. How about the following?

```
The most impactful types of information to partition are (a) user identity or identities that can be linked and (b) user data, which can be user-identifying for certain applications.
```

I guess this sentence is not wrong but not sure it's the point. E.g. if I visit videosofcats.com with my IP address, someone who observes the traffic knows that I love cats. So separating this information is useful. If I visit myprivatepageofcatvideos.org where I'm the only user ever visiting this page, an observer can identify me no matter if they see my IP address or not. Hiding the IP address might still be important to not correlate this traffic with other traffic. But isn't the first case the most/more important one, where the user data in itself in not user-identifying?
Yep, and that's an example of how this principle, even if applied correctly, is insufficient in many cases. This PR does acknowledge this limitation, so I don't think further changes are needed here.
So why is “which can be user-identifying for certain applications” needed?
isn't the most impactful partition to separate user-identifying data from non-user-identifying data?

```suggestion
The most impactful types of information to partition are (a) user identity or identities (such as an account name or IP address) that can be linked and (b) user data (such as the content a user is accessing), which can be often sensitive when combined with user identity. Note that user data can itself be user-identifying, in which case it should be treated as an identifier.
```
Yeah, but I'll change this to "context" for now. We can converge on a standard term later.

```suggestion
This partitioning process can be applied incorrectly or incompletely. Contexts may contain
```
The entities are part of the context, so I think it's simpler as-is.
(Is this now resolved?)
I think this is now resolved based on the change below?

I proposing this change because it is not at all clear what is means to evaluate the context that exists. I would say this evaluation is actually to identify the contexts itself, which means you identify all entities that below to a context and the information that is shared in this context.

No, this is a separate point: "minimising amount of user-identifying or correlatable information in any single context" is a too strong goal. Earlier we say you want to "minimise to the information needed to fulfil a certain function". That's something different.

```suggestion
1. Partition user data such that the amount of user-identifying or correlatable information in each context is reduced to the minimum needed to fulfil the intended function.
```

```suggestion
1.  Partition data to minimize the amount of user-identifying or correlatable information in any given context to only include what is necessary for that context, and prevent sharing of data across contexts wherever possible.
```

```suggestion
|  | Client +----Proxied-----+   Proxy   +--------------+ Target |  |
```

```suggestion
|  | Client +----------Proxied----------+ Proxy +-------+ Target |  |
```

pulls.title: Separate contexts are only useful if other factors are disjoint

```suggestion
MAC addresses, device properties, software properties and behavior, application state, etc).
```

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: @mirjak what do you think of the text now?

```suggestion
Some information is innate to client user-agents, including details of implementation of
```

```suggestion
```
Do you have this heading twice or am I not able to read the diff correctly?
this heading is not saying much. Would we be able to find a more meaningful heading for this part?
I also see a duplicate heading. @chris-wood What was the intention?
I think I liked the old phrasing here better, of just calling the second chunk the user data. Maybe user-generated or user-selected data?
We distinguish between user-identifying and non-user-identifying, so I think it's better to keep this distinction here.
Probably, but it's not obvious to me what that would be.
It sounds odd to have that be “or user data”. Perhaps we can say “non-user-identifying content the user is accessing or generating”?
How about “User-identifying information” or “Fingerprinting”, etc

```suggestion
linked and (b) non-user-identifying information (including content a user
generates or accesses), which can be often sensitive when combined with user identity.
```
I don't think it's much of an improvement, but that works.

```suggestion
## User-Identifying Information
```

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: @chris-wood @mirjak can you review before the deadline today?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
I think this PR is good but not sure if it fully address the issue in #40. I think initially these protocol have been developed for every different use case and we in this draft don't question or discuss this, we only observe that they are all because on the same principle.

So Martin question is now, if I have a new use case which of these protocols should I use? Not sure if that even works that way because all of the protocols have a certain use case and if you have a different use case you might need yet another protocol applying the same design principle however. Don't know.

I guess we could talk about more about the uses cases that these protocols have been developed for. The Other interesting question is, would it be possible to cover all these use case with one protocol....? No idea...

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: @mirjak I think this is the degree to which we can respond to the issue now — this isn't a guide for which protocol you need to choose, but rather explains (as Martin asked for) why there are different approaches and what makes them different. These are the factors you need to consider when selecting a set of protocols to use.

```suggestion
While all of the partitioning protocols described in this document separate contexts
using cryptography, connection separation, or a combination of the two, each one has a
```

Because DAP doesn't need connection separation -- it just uses secret sharing.

```suggestion
partitioning, including:
```

To make more clear that this list is not exhaustive.

```suggestion
depending on if tokens can be cached and reused. CONNECT-style proxying and
Oblivious HTTP often require bidirectional and interactive communication.
```

I wouldn't say that OHTTP requires bidirectional communication since apps could implement fire-and-forget (clients POST and then don't care about the response).

```suggestion
- The threat model, and in particular whether or not the servers providing support for context
separation are trusted. The degree to which contexts need to be partitioned depends on part
on how much clients trust them with such information. For example, in Oblivious HTTP, clients
trust relays to learn that clients are accessing a particular application-specific gateway. If clients
do not trust relays with this option, they may opt for a multi-hop CONNECT-style proxy approach
wherein no single party learns whether specific clients are accessing a specific application. Indeed,
this is the default trust model for systems like Tor, where multiple hops are used to drive down the
probability of privacy violations due to collusion or related attacks.
```

This first sentence seem broken, so maybe I don't get the point. However, I think this is all pretty much the core of what this document says but I would put is the other way a round - in order to minimise the needed trust, you should partition your data as much as you can - however this means of course also if you can't partition certain data because that's needed for the functionality you are requesting, then you might need a higher level of trust the more data you share (or maybe it's not so much about the "amount" of data but more particularly about the kind of data).

This suggested point is that the trust model dictates how you partition, which is not a factor we explicitly cover in either of the other two points, which are mostly about compatibility with existing systems and usability.

```suggestion
While all of the partitioning protocols described in this document create
separate contexts using encryption and/or connection separation, each one has a
```
Yeah I think this is a good point to add, but I think we should make the first sentence complete.

```suggestion
- The degree to which contexts need to be partitioned depends in part
on the client's threat models and level of trust in various protocol participants. For example,
in Oblivious HTTP, clients allow relays to learn that clients are accessing a particular
application-specific gateway. If clients do not trust relays with this information, they can
instead use a multi-hop CONNECT-style proxy approach wherein no single party learns
whether specific clients are accessing a specific application. This is the default trust model
for systems like Tor, where multiple hops are used to drive down the probability of privacy
violations due to collusion or related attacks.
```

```suggestion
violations due to collusion or related attacks.

```

pulls.title: Add text about RFC6973 to intro
pulls.author: mirjak

comments.body:
```suggestion
RFC6973 discusses the use of identity management systems for data minimization.
```

```suggestion
{{?RFC6973}} already discusses data minimization, especially in the context of
user identity and identity management systems.
```

```suggestion
Privacy partitioning as defined in this document goes further, to consider different deployment
```

I'm not sure this identity provider detail belongs in our intro? I think it is different than the privacy pass approach — the RFC6973 text seems to be more about only collecting what you need for an account, etc.

```suggestion
{{?RFC6973}} discusses data minimization, especially in the context of
user identity and identity management systems.
```

```suggestion
privacy partitioning, similar as used for privacy pass (see Section {{privacypass}}).
```

```suggestion
models that can create multiple contexts where data is minimized in each context.
```
